name: benzyl-o-tolyl-amine
Reason: The given compound benzyl-o-tolyl-amine is composed of a benzyl group (C6H5CH2-) and an o-tolyl group (2-methylphenyl) attached to an amine (-NH2). For the benzene ring as a base unit, the starting melting point is 5.5°C. Each phenyl ring with substituents will slightly increase the melting point due to the increase in molecular weight and potential for π-π stacking interactions. The methyl group on the o-tolyl group will increase the melting point as well, but less significantly than the introduction of another phenyl ring. The presence of the amine group generally increases the melting point due to the possibility of hydrogen bonding, which adds additional intermolecular forces. Assuming a phenyl ring adds approximately 40°C to the melting point because of increased molecular weight and intermolecular interactions, and a methyl group adds around 5°C due to its smaller size but non-negligible addition to the molecular weight and van der Waals interactions. The linkage of the benzyl to the o-tolyl group might slightly influence the melting point due to steric hindrance, but not significantly. Amine may add around 20°C due to its hydrogen bonding capability.
